title: PURPOSE/OBJECTIVE
content: To create an effective management system that will ensure Safety and Health at Sea, prevention of human injury or loss of Life, and avoidance of damage to the Environment, in particular, to marine environment and to property in all Company activities.

title: SCOPE
content: Developing and maintaining safety management system to implement policy through Company procedures/instructions and environmental excellence in all shipboard activities. These procedures and instructions apply to all vessels as defined by the ISM code.

title: LEGAL AND REGULATORY REQUIREMENTS
content:
The following amplifies the Company's policy with respect to mandatory regulations and laws:

  1. All ships will be operated according to the following rules, regulations and amendments as applicable and in force:
    1. International Convention on Load Lines
    2. International Convention for the Safety of Life at Sea
    3. MARPOL
    4. Maritime Labor Convention (MLC)
    5. International Regulations for Preventing Collisions at Sea
    6. International Convention on Tonnage Measurement on Ships
    7. Code of Federal Regulations, Title 33
    8. IMO Resolution pertaining to Principles of Safe Manning
    9. STCW Conventions
    10. ILO Conventions
    11. BHC/ IBC Code
    12. IMDG Code
    13. GC/IGC Code
    14. MEPC - Marine Environment Protection Committee
    15. EmS - Emergency procedures for Ships carrying Dangerous Goods
    16. OPRC Convention
    17. International Convention on Oil Pollution Preparedness, Response and Co-operation & SOPEP
    18. ICS and Regional requirements and regulations
  2. The applicable rules, regulations, guidelines and standards of the IMO, flag state of the vessel, Classification societies and maritime industry organizations.

title: VISION AND MISSION STATEMENT
content:
Vision

To be recognized as a premier ship Management Company active in a number of specialized

and diverse shipping segments.

Mission

To provide to a variety of customers, either directly or through Business Partners and Affiliated companies, ship management services which are:

  1. Delivering the highest HSSE standards
  2. Reliable
  3. Cost effective
  4. Meeting or exceeding customer requirement
  5. In accordance with all applicable quality, safety and environmental standards
  6. Aimed at achieving zero incident, zero spill and reduction in emissions with continuous
  7. improvement.
  8. Reduction in permitted emission
  9. Above Vision & Mission statement is provided in the form of a Poster (S – 1.2 P) which should be posted at appropriate locations onboard.

title: COMPANY POLICIES
content:
Stated below are the Company’s 11 - fundamental policies which form the basis of vessel operation. Master is responsible to ensure that all operations involving the vessel is conducted in strict accordance with these policies.

Company policies are published in the form of a Poster (S – 1.3 P) which should be posted at appropriate locations onboard to make crew familiar and to serve as a constant reminder of Company policies at all times.

title: QUALITY
content:
It is a Company policy to provide to our customers ship management services which are – reliable, cost effective, meeting or exceeding customer requirements, always in accordance with all applicable compliance/obligations. Company commits to continual improvement of the management system.

Company is committed & will comply fully with all international statutory requirements such as ISM Code, SOLAS, Marpol and requirements established under International, Flag State, Port State, and Coastal State Laws including but not limited to.

title: OCCUPATIONAL HEALTH AND SAFETY
content:
It is the Company’s Policy to provide a safe and healthy workplace environment for shore based and shipboard personnel and the Company is committed to:

  • Prevent loss of life, work-related injury or illness by promoting safe and healthy practices and proper planning and execution of operations.
  • Comply with applicable requirements that relate to Occupational Health and Safety (OH&S).
  • Establish its own standards and guidelines where existing laws and regulations are not adequate to assure protection to human health and safety.
  • Establish clear OH&S objectives and targets towards minimizing risk potentials and protect all staff working on board ships by the use of appropriate technology and operating procedures.
  • Encourage all individuals to identify potentially unsafe conditions or unlawful practices and to undertake corrective measures.
  • Provide all its employees with information, equipment and training necessary for them to carry out their work safely.
  • Ensure that regular safety and contingency drills are conducted by the Master and at times supervised by the shore based personnel for ensuring that relevant personnel are fully conversant with their duties so as to maintain a confident and proficient team on board to deal with all contingencies and emergencies.
  • Ensure that Safety is uppermost in mind in all Company instructions.
  • Continuous improvement in OH&S management and OH&S performance.
  • Not allowing commercial aspects to jeopardise safety of crew or vessel.

title: ETHIC AND NON-RETALIATION
content:
It is the Company’s Policy to ensure that all shore based and ship based personnel carry out their duties in an ethical and honest manner ensuring that they exhibit the highest standards of integrity and righteousness at all times. The Company is committed to:

  1. Ensure that no shore based employee or personnel onboard ships under Management, participates in any incentive or bonus programs based on minimizing operational costs associated with the operation, maintenance, and repair of machinery space systems, equipment, and components without ensuring that efficiency and performance are maintained. The intent of this is to ensure that staff do not avoid such costs and thereby sacrifice environmental compliance.
  2. Take appropriate action, up to and including dismissal, against any shore based employee or personnel onboard ships under Management who obstruct, hinder or present false information, or make false statements during any inspection; monitoring or audit carried out by any authority whatsoever.
  3. Ensure that NO shore based employee or personnel onboard ships under Management are punished, discriminated against or otherwise suffers negative consequences for reporting violations of QHSE laws, regulations, or policies.
  4. Take disciplinary action up to and including dismissal against any shore based employee or personnel onboard ships under Management who depart from specified operating policies and procedures.

Shore based employees and personnel onboard ships under Management may also be personally liable for criminal, civil or administrative penalties as a result of non-compliance.

title: ANTI-BRIBERY & TRADE COMPLIANCE
content:
Company’s Compliance Policy is set out in Quality Management Manual Section 2.1.2.3 & in QHSE Manual Section 2.3. The Company is committed to adhering to the highest standards of ethical behaviour in the conduct of its worldwide business dealings. It has a zero tolerance approach towards all forms of unethical behaviour, bribery or corruption in the public and private sectors, and any other conduct that can expose the Company, its Employees and Associated Persons to reputational harm or criminal prosecution.

The Company is fully committed to complying with sanctions legislation/regulations emanating from the UK, EU, UN and US which are applicable and to ensure that;

(i) No business is conducted with a Designated Entity or prohibited activity engaged in; and (ii) No payments are made via a designated bank and/or to or from a Designated Entity.

The Company has developed Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) that sets out the procedures that the Company has put in place to ensure that there is no breach of the Policy, compliance with the SOP is mandatory for all Company employees.

All Company employees both onboard as well as ashore are required to be fully compliant with the Company’s Compliance Policy and immediately report to Company if any wrong practice is observed with respect to it.

title: HARASSMENT AND BULLYING IN THE WORKPLACE POLICY
content:
Company is committed to providing a work environment which is free from harassment. It is the Company policy to prohibit any form of harassment and bullying in any workplace whether in the office or onboard company managed ships.

Harassment covers a range of behaviours, including subtle and not-so-subtle, verbal and non-verbal behaviour. It can be engaged in or experienced by both males and females. The Company will not tolerate any form of harassment at any level. Harassment includes:

  1. Telling jokes or making verbal or physical innuendoes which are unwelcome and explicitly or implicitly belittle an individual’s sex, race, colour, religion, sexual orientation, gender identity, national origin, ancestry, disability, or age
  2. Engaging in verbal or physical conduct of a sexual nature, including (for example) conduct that expressly or implicitly constitutes an unwelcome sexual advance or a request for sexual acts or favours
  3. Making an unwelcome verbal request of a sexual nature, e.g. suggestions that sexual cooperation will affect an employment decision or is a condition of an individuals continued employment
  4. Taking or failing to take a personnel action (e.g. firing, demoting, failing to promote) in reprisal for an employee’s rejecting or reporting an inappropriate conduct of a sexual nature
  5. Failing to take appropriate action in response to an employee’s reporting a harassing conduct (e.g. failing to investigate charges)
  6. Creating an intimidating, hostile, humiliating, or offensive work environment by means of verbal or physical conduct of a harassing nature
  7. Subjecting others to obscenity or offensive language (which might include displaying offensive, electronic communication, cyber bullying or sexually suggestive photographs, objects, pictures, cartoons, graffiti, etc., using offensive language in situations where others are certain to hear it, and similar conduct);
  8. Graphic commentary about an individual’s body, sexual prowess or sexual deficiencies, or
  9. Leering, whistling, touching, pinching, assault.

This kind of behaviour is unacceptable both in offices and in any work-related setting outside our offices such as during business trips, on office outings, at parties, business- related social events and on board company managed ships.

The Company will follow local laws and regulations in terms of procedure in jurisdictions where a certain procedure is mandated. All complaints of harassment and bullying will be treated and in strict confidence.

title: DRUG AND ALCOHOL
content:
The Company is committed to maintain a safe and healthy working environment, free from the unauthorised use of drugs and alcohol, for all employees.

The Company recognizes that alcohol, drug, or other substance abuse by employees may impair their ability to perform properly and will have serious adverse effects on the safety, efficiency and productivity of other employees and the Company as a whole. The misuse of legitimate drugs, or the use, possession, distribution or sale of illicit or un-prescribed drugs on company business or Company ships, is strictly prohibited and is grounds for termination. Being unfit for work because of use of alcohol or drugs is strictly prohibited and is grounds for termination of employment.

The Company may conduct unannounced searches for alcohol and/or drugs on Company ships. Unannounced periodic or random testing will be conducted when an employee meets any one of the following conditions:

- either the Individual has had a substance abuse problem

- or is working in a designated position identified by the Company

- or in a position where testing is required by law

Reasons for such testing may include:

- for cause   - post-incident      - pre-employment

- follow-up  - reasonable suspicion  - random types of testing

Contractors sailing as ship's complement are subject to the provisions of the Company’s Drug & Alcohol Policy and Procedures. Visitors, contractors and vendor's personnel will be subject to the same standards for search and inspection as the ship's complement in regard to alcohol, drugs and controlled or illegal substances while on Company ships. Failure to comply with this Policy in this regard may result in removal from the ship and denial of future access.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL
content:
It is the Company’s Policy to work towards a cleaner marine environment and the Company is committed to:

  1. Firmly support the International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships (MARPOL) and other environmental requirements and believing that the first line of defence against pollution must be to avoid accidents occurring.
  2. Comply with applicable marine environmental protection requirements established under International, Flag State, Port State and Coastal State Laws including but not limited to the International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships (MARPOL), concerning the use of Oily Water Separators, Oil Content Meters, Incinerators and other Pollution Prevention Equipment.
  3. Improving Energy efficiency and reducing GHG emissions from managed vessels.

Company is committed to achieve Zero spill with continuous improvements through:

  1. Continuous improvement in environmental performance, including those areas in the Environmental Management System.
  2. Pollution prevention with an emphasis on source reduction, including the funding and human resources necessary to effectively maintain and repair the systems, equipment, and components found in machinery spaces of vessels.
  3. Continuous reduction of environmental risks.
  4. Sharing information with external stakeholders on environmental performance.
  5. Undertake steps in energy conservation to help address the problem of depleting natural resources and its impact on the environment.

Company has a Zero Tolerance approach to any non-compliance/violation of above policy and will extend fill cooperation to authorities in brining offenders to books.

title: PERSONNEL / WELFARE
content:
The Company recognizes that safety, environment protection, efficiency and welfare are an integral part of good ship management which can only be a result of a combination of right skills, knowledge and experience ashore and onboard vessels.

In order to accomplish the desired objectives as well as provide and maintain the highest standards of ship management, the company is committed to:

  1. Employ staff having adequate qualifications, skills, knowledge and experience to serve in the rank or position they have been selected for.
  2. Employ only those seafarers who are mentally and physically sound and medically fit to effectively execute the set objectives of the Company.
  3. Inculcate a sense of loyalty and dedication and to encourage a sense of belonging to become long serving employees of the Company.
  4. Providestaffashoreandafloatwithinformationandtrainingnecessaryforthemtofully understand the Company’s QHSE System.
  5. EnsurethatcompliancewiththeQHSEstandardsisakeyingredientintheidentification of training needs and performance reviews of shore and shipboard personnel
  6. Company will always follow“JustCulture”while implementing its policies on personnel.
  7. The Company is committed to producing a caring and supportive working environment which is conducive to the welfare of all employees, and which enables them to develop
  8. towards their full potential.

title: SECURITY & CYBER SECURITY
content:
It is the Company’s policy to:

  1. Provide a secure working environment, by establishing and maintaining the required security measures to prevent unlawful acts against ships which endanger the safety and security of persons/property on board and the environment.
  2. Ensure that the Master, Company Security Officer and the Ship Security Officer are given necessary support to fulfil their duties and responsibilities in accordance with IMO’s draft amendments to SOLAS Chapter XI-2 and the ISPS Code.

The Master has the overriding authority and responsibility to make decisions regarding the security of the ship and to request the assistance of the Company or of any Contracting Government as may be necessary.

All Company employees, ashore and on board ships, are expected to comply with the required procedures within the Ship Security Plan and should be familiar with the relevant security duties required of them and the measures required to protect the ship from any unlawful act. Complying with and maintaining ship security is a continuous process and as new potential threats are uncovered, additional security procedures and measures shall be devised and implemented.

Company is committed to effectively manage Cyber Risks as part of the overall approach to safety & security management, including safety culture, and the protection of Environment. The Cyber Risk Management (CRM) has both Safety and Security aspects, and emphasis is on managing the safety risks introduced by OT, IT systems and connectivity.

It is Company’s policy to place adequate Technical and Procedural risk protection and control measures, to prevent disruption of OT, IT systems and connectivity, which may affect the safe operation and/or protection of the environment. Such Cyber Risk Management measures include, but are not limited to:

  1. - Identifying vulnerable IT/OT systems and putting adequate protection/detection measures against cyber risks.
  2. - Controlling Physical/Connectivity/Logical access to vulnerable OT, IT systems.
  3. - Controlling use of Personal devices (Laptops, Phones, Tablets, etc.) and Portable media (USB, CD’s, etc).
  4. - Management of Passwords, Administrative privileges, Anti-virus/malware updates.
  5. - Controlling Third party access, Contractor/Vendor management and Remote access to OT, IT systems.
  6. - Cyber Incident Management through a Cyber Response Plan and placing adequate recovery measures.
  7. - Promoting Cyber Awareness and Training of Staff, and Responsible Cyber-safe behaviours and Best practices.

title: SOCIAL MEDIA POLICY
content:
It is the Company’s policy to ensure that that all shore based and ship based personnel use the internet in a responsible manner. All are personally responsible for the content they publish on-line, whether in a blog, social computing site or any other form of user- generated media. Be mindful that what you publish will be public for a long time.

  1. They should be careful about what information and images they make available to others on the Internet about the Company and Company’s managed vessels.
  2. Do not act in an inappropriate manner, intentionally or otherwise, and do not communicate any confidential information or other sensitive matters online and to third parties.
  3. Do not publish content that might allow inferences to be drawn which could damage Company’s reputation or any relationship with the Company.
  4. Do not use ethnic slurs, discriminatory remarks, personal insults, obscenity, or engage in any similar conduct.
  5. Show proper consideration for others' privacy.

All Company employees, ashore and on-board ships, are expected to comply with the required procedures within the Safety Management System pertaining to Social Media and appropriate use of internet.

title: SOCIAL RESPONSIBILITY
content:
Company has a long-standing commitment to social responsibility through its parent organization, Caravel Group, Hong Kong.

The Group strives to confront today’s most pressing issues. We combine our talents and experience with that of reputable and well established organizations in order to make a meaningful difference. From enhancing the wellbeing of the world’s seafarers to giving children a better start to life, no challenge is too demanding for the team.

title: MANAGEMENT COMMITMENT, AUTHORITY AND RESPONSIBILITY
content:
Company is committed to promote safety and environmental excellence at all levels, as stated in its vision and mission statement. To achieve this, Company sets out high level and long term goals against which the Company performance is assessed during Annual management reviews.

The Company management will conduct quarterly and annual management reviews as per the schedule to assess overall performance. During such reviews, the status of non- conformances, actions resulting from incidents / nearmisses etc are reviewed and progress in closing them is assessed and summarized.

Monitoring and measurement results as achieved, results of evaluation of compliance with legal requirements and other requirements, review on consultation and participation of shore and on-board staff, evaluate the risks and opportunities, determine adequacy of resources for maintaining an effective quality. Environmentally sound and holistic OH&S management system verify on relevant communication(s) with interested parties and access on opportunities for continual improvement.

Head of Quality & Safety is tasked with maintaining records indicating the extent of management involvement in these activities. He will also promulgate the summary of the management review meetings and Company KPI’s to Fleet.

Master is tasked with the responsibility of achieving Safety targets, Environmental targets as well Occupational health and safety targets as promulgated by the Office. The Safety, Environment and OSHAS KPI’s set-out by the Company shall be tracked on a monthly basis and performance against these KPI’s shall be recorded in Monthly Safety committee meeting (S – 9.1 F).

title: MANAGEMENT COMMITMENT, AUTHORITY AND RESPONSIBILITY
content:
It is a Company expectation that all its employees ashore and onboard fully understand and describe practical implementation of HSSE excellence. These include but are not limited to;

  • Best Practices are encouraged and promoted across the fleet
  • Lessons learnt from Incidents / nearmisses etc (own as well fleet as well as from Industry sources) are regularly communicated to fleet by following:

   - Mission statement cards

   - Vessel visit by suptds and / or seafarers visiting shore offices

   - Safety bulletins / Alerts

   - Company News letters

   - Vessels feedback etc

  • Company promotes and measures personnel understanding through following;

   - Safety induction and familiarization programmes

   - Vessel visit by suptds and / or seafarers visiting shore offices

   - Company seminars

   - Computer based trainings onboard as well as ashore

   - Informal meetings/personnel interviews during superintendent visit onboard Ship/Shore communications

title: QUALITY & SAFETY MANAGEMENT SYSTEM
content:
NON-CONFORMANCE

It is defined as a disagreement between actual features and the specified requirements and the purpose of identifying non-conformance is to establish a uniform guide for taking appropriate corrective action when a non-conformance occurs. It shall not be limited only to consumables supplied to the vessel but also to problems arising with vessel's equipment, personnel, various onboard incidents like accidents & near-misses, customer complaints and contingency planning.

REPORTING, REVIEWING & DISPOSITION OF NON-CONFORMANCE

The method of identifying a nonconforming item shall depend on the nature of the product or service being provided. To some extent these may be identified during the normal course of work, by judging its performance or through inspections and internal audits.

Non-conformities and non – compliances reported or observed by ship’s staff shall be recorded in the PARIS system or in the ‘Safety Committee Meeting & Safety/ Pollution Prevention Review (S – 9.1 F).

Deficiencies noted during PSC and other inspections shall be reported to the office who will enter the deficiency into the PARIS system for analysis, follow up and close out. A separate NCN Note is not required.

It is Master’s responsibility to report Port State Control detentions / interventions to the Flag Administration with copy to the Company. The report should also indicate corrective action taken to rectify the deficiencies / defects.

Whenever a Third Party inspection is carried out, the results of the inspection should be advised promptly to the Head Office by fax/ email. The message should also indicate corrective action taken to rectify the deficiencies / defects.

It shall be the responsibility of the person identifying the non-conformance to report to the concerned head of the department or the management, as the case may be.

In general the Master shall be responsible to report all onboard nonconformities including deficiencies from PSC and other inspections to the office by e. mail and on PARIS.

CONSUMABLES

All stores and spares supplied to the vessel shall be checked by the Chief Officer and/or the Chief Engineer to verify whether they meet the requirement and report to the Master. In case of any nonconformity the Master shall report the matter to the office. The Technical Department will then take necessary corrective action. To prevent inadvertent use, till such time they are off landed, these items shall be kept away from its normal storing place and clearly identified.

The Master shall be responsible to ensure that the vessel has relevant up to date publications and voyage charts for the intended voyage. Any shortfalls shall be reported to the office and is to be supported by a requisition.

The Senior Superintendent / Superintendent in-charge for the vessel shall be responsible to review same and make necessary arrangements for supplying the applicable charts and publications promptly.

EQUIPMENT

Equipment shall be stated to be nonconforming if during the course of the service it fails to perform to its specified requirement either as a result of breakdown or poor performance. The person responsible for handling the equipment shall report such deficiencies to the office through the Master.

The Senior Superintendent / Superintendent for the vessel shall at the same time be responsible to monitor the performance of the vessels equipment on the basis of the reports received from the vessel and routine inspection of the vessel. Reasons for such nonconformity shall be reviewed by the Senior Superintendent / Superintendent who shall issue appropriate advice or corrective actions to be taken to the vessel.

Dependent on the seriousness of the nonconformity and till such time remedial actions are taken, suitable warning placards shall be placed against the equipment or its starting panel to avoid inadvertent use.

ACCIDENTS / INCIDENTS / NEAR MISSES / NON-COMPLIANCES

All onboard accidents, incidents, Near-misses and non-compliance are to be promptly reported to the office by the Master as per the procedures given in section 8 of this manual. The Incident and Nearmiss module in PARIS provides a formal and systematic report, investigation and analysis of the incident / nearmisses and is to be filled up by the Master after proper investigation has been carried out. The PARIS system generate a pdf file in the format (S – 8.1 F) which can be printed and filed onboard, as necessary. If PARIS is not operational, the Incident / Nearmiss investigation can be carried out using company form (S – 8.1 F).

LEADING INDICATORS – Being a leading indicator, Company places a great importance on reporting, analyzing and learning from Near-misses. In order to fully utilize this process in “Accident prevention”, the Near-miss reporting process is divided into following 3 - categories:

a) Nearmisses

b) Hazardous occurrence

c) SAFER+ Observations

The PARIS system provided onboard allows raising of nearmisses by any personnel i.e. ship’s crew as well as any visitor who may raise Nearmisses using internet.

At least two of the ships personnel must have undergone an incident investigation training course.

title: INTERNAL COMMUNICATION
content:
The Master shall ensure that that an appropriate formal communication process is established between personnel at various levels and functions.

Meetings held onboard:

a) Daily work plan meeting

b) Weekly Meetings – Discuss on Housekeeping / Cleanliness and hygiene conditions after Master’s weekly accommodation inspection

c) Monthly safety committee meeting

d) Brief safety meeting following an incident / serious nearmiss or upon receipt of “Urgent safety matter” or “Safety Flash” from Office

e) Tool-box meetings

f) Miscellaneous meetings as per the circumstances e.g. post voyage de-brief, Master’s review of SMS etc.

title: DOCUMENT CONTROL SYSTEM
content:
All vessels shall carry relevant Company SMS manuals, logs, forms and checklists applicable to the vessel type. These are controlled documents and are subject to revisions. Each SMS documents is provided with revision history and a control numbers. Any change to such documents must comply with the requirements of ‘Management of Change’ procedures.

Master is responsible for ensuring that only the latest and valid documents are used onboard his vessel. All obsolete documents are to be promptly removed.

Note: Paper version of the QHSE manual is the primary and electronic version on PARIS is for reference only.

title: DISTRIBUTION OF MANUALS

The Head of Quality and Safety shall distribute each manual according to the distribution list as below. Documents in all manuals at each workstation shall be maintained up-to-date with current versions.

QMM ManualFor Office only
QHSE ManualFor all ships
Cargo Operation Manual As per ship type
Forms and ChecklistsFor all ships and offices

Distribution of manuals or copies of its content to persons outside of the company is strictly prohibited, unless authorized by the Head of Quality and Safety. When a vessel leaves the company’s management, the Master shall be responsible for removing all Quality & Safety management manuals and other necessary documentation from the vessel. The QHSE manual should be located in Navigational Bridge and Cargo Operation Manual to be located in Cargo Control Room.

As an exception, the Master may authorize copying of forms, checklists and appendixes which are used for record keeping.

title: DISTRIBUTION OF UPDATES TO SHIPS
content:
The QHSE manual and associated forms, checklists, Logs and posters are regularly reviewed taking into account learning from audits, Master’s Reviews, Management Reviews, change in Company's policy, regulatory changes, learning from incidents and input/feedback from various departments of the Company, Risk Assessments, Suggestions for continual improvement and recommendation from Industry bodies.

Company encourages proactive feedback from users including shore-based personnel, vessel personnel and third parties. These include but are not limited to;

  • Circulating industry and fleet incidents
  • Industry alert bulletins
  • Customer and contractor feedback forms
  • Seminars
  • Open reporting programmes
  • Group conferencing etc.

Such review of Company SMS will be held whenever any need for revision arises. After this review, any change in SMS procedures will be promulgated to fleet through OPERATION or TECHNICAL circulars which shall have the same statutory value as the SMS procedures contained in the manuals. If the governing circular has any change or deviation from the procedures already contained in the SMS manual, Masters must indicate so manually on the concerned page of the manual and a copy of the relevant circular shall be attached therein.

Once every 6 month i.e. in June and Dec of the year, the QHSE manual will be thoroughly revised taking in to account, among other things, all previously issued circulars which will be included in the QHSE manual. Once the content of the circular has been incorporated in the QHSE manual, the concerned circulars will be permanently withdrawn from circular files.

title: STANDARD LIBRARY / REFERENCE DOCUMENTS
content:
Company has included a number of regulatory publication and industry guidelines in its “Standard Library” to be maintained onboard as well as ashore. Once every month, the latest edition of publications included in standard library is reviewed and circulated to all vessels.

In addition, Company subscribes to “Regs for Ships”, a web-based service provider which promptly alerts Company about any changes in above publications.

Once vessel receives the Circular O-2 containing the regulatory publications Section 1.2 A of QHSE manual to be updated with the same.

title: MASTER’S REVIEW OF QUALITY AND SAFETY MANAGEMENT SYSTEM
css: table { font-family: arial, sans-serif; border-collapse: collapse; width: 100%; } td, th { min-width:fit-content; border: 1px solid #000; text-align: left; padding: 8px; } td { font-size: 12px }
content:
The Master’s reviews will be invited from all vessels under management once every 2 Months. The Master review will involve the following:

  1. Review of a shipboard process
  2. Review of Company’s SMS element

While review of shipboard processes will be need based i.e. resulting from an identified weakness in the system or due to new regulations etc, the Company’s SMS element review subjects are pre-decided as per table, given here below:

Following planner will be used for Master’s review:

Note: Section 13 of the QHSE Manual, “Security Procedures” and Ship Security Plan will be reviewed at least once a year during the Master’s Annual Security Review using form (ISPS – 12), contained in vessel’s approved Ship Security Plan (SSP).

All vessels are required to submit Master’s review once every 2 months using company form (S - 1.1 F). The Master’s review will be analyzed by the Company and suitable feedback will be sent to Fleet.

title: VISIBLE & FELT LEADERSHIP
content:
Sr. Management of the Company will visit a few ships to promote Safety and Environmental excellence. Gist of such visit will be shared with the Fleet and discussed during the Company held seminars.

Company has published a Safety Empowerment poster (S – 1.7 P) wherein the Managing Director is seen empowering vessels crew to always follow safe practices and utilize their STOP WORK Authority to avoid undesired Incidents.

title: SUPERINTENDENT’S VISIT
css: table { font-family: arial, sans-serif; border-collapse: collapse; width: 100%; } td, th { min-width:fit-content; border: 1px solid #dddddd; text-align: center; padding: 8px; } td { font-size: 12px }
content:
Superintendents will visit vessel at regular interval. During this visit, in addition to vessel inspection, Superintendent will emphasize upon Company goal of “ZERO INCIDENT” through;

  • Holding safety meeting with all available staff
  • Raising Nearmiss / Hazards or SAFER+ observations on PARIS and discussion with crew during the shipboard safety meeting
  • Best Practices noted and uploaded on PARIS for benefit of all vessels in Fleet
  • Holding Socializing Safety Work shop (SSW) under SAFER+ - at least one / year
  • All above and any safety feedback as well as recommendations for improvement are to be recorded in Company form DE-28C.
